image.altText: NT parliament building

props.synopsis: The NT government says the territory coordinator bill, set to pass parliament this week, will be the "most important piece of economic reform" seen in a decade. So what is set to change?

title.children: What is the NT's territory coordinator bill and what laws could it override?

image.altText: Two Indigenous women smile at the camera in a composite image that includes a black and white photo and red desert.

props.synopsis: It has been more than 40 years since the Pintupi Nine made contact with the modern world. Much has changed in their lives, but their country has never stopped calling them home.

title.children: For years, these sisters didn't know white people existed

image.altText: An Aboriginal young woman, with black hair and a red stripe, holding a paint brush while dying someone's hair.

props.synopsis: Whether it's a fade, mullet or colours, a mobile salon set up in a shipping container out bush is giving Indigenous students access to haircuts and the opportunity to learn the trade.

title.children: 'People are thrilled': New remote salon ends hours-long trip for a cut

image.altText: Cleared land with two lone trees in the middle.

props.synopsis: The owners of Claravale Farm, who cleared 286 hectares of the property without a land-clearing permit, have reached a settlement with the Northern Territory government.

title.children: Farm owners settle with NT government over unpermitted land clearing

image.altText: NT Police Commissioner Michael Murphy speaking into a microphone in front of a crowd and looking emotional.

props.synopsis: Michael Murphy had planned to deliver a second apology to Aboriginal people in the remote Northern Territory. But after his sudden departure, there’s no certainty it will happen.

title.children: Unfinished business: NT top cop's departure leaves second apology unsaid

image.altText: Justice Blokland in robes on the bench

props.synopsis: Presiding over the worst categories of offending in the NT Supreme Court, Judge Jenny Blokland is afforded a unique view of how justice is served. Her estimates are sobering.

title.children: Judge urges radical rethink of NT's 'wicked problem'

image.altText: man covers his head with a jumper to ward off the sun

props.synopsis: A new study by Australian researchers finds that the risk of cardiovascular disease increases with higher temperatures, and the burden could double by 2050 if extreme heat continues.

title.children: Heart disease set to soar in Australia as temperatures rise, study suggests

image.altText: A man stands on a sporting oval that is covered in white hail stones. He is holding four large hail stones.

props.synopsis: The 1999 Sydney hailstorm was a wake-up call, exposing how vulnerable our cities could be to extreme weather.

title.children: 'The mother of all storms' hit Sydney. It was a wake-up call for our cities

image.altText: TAX CUTS Peter Dutton, Jane Hume, Angus Taylor 20240206_012902275_iOS

props.synopsis: The Coalition's proposed limit for the rate of taxation has not been exceeded for nearly 20 years, and the party appears reluctant to offer new tax cuts before the election.

title.children: Coalition's tax 'speed limit' branded 'shallow' and would not require tax cuts

image.altText: A herd of AACo's wagyu heifers at Westholme station in Queensland.

props.synopsis: A theory for their cause of death was that a tap from a water tank to a trough was accidentally off. The deaths have horrified people in the agriculture industry, and marks more turmoil at AACo.

title.children: Cattle herd owned by luxury beef giant AACo died of apparent thirst

image.altText: Donald Trump and Vladimir Putin

props.synopsis: The US president says he wants to discuss land and the future of Ukraine's power plants and "dividing up certain assets" on the call with his Russian counterpart.

title.children: Trump, Putin to talk as 30 countries set to join post-war Ukraine 'coalition'

image.altText: Abdullah Farzad dismounts his electric bicycle as he prepared to make an Uber Eats delivery to a Melbourne hotel at night.

props.synopsis: While most of Australia is sleeping, more than 1 million workers are supporting the $174 billion night-time economy.

title.children: Inside the lives of the million Australians working after hours

image.altText: A man with payos curls, a black hat, and beard

props.synopsis: Fighting wars on multiple fronts has left Israel's military ranks severely depleted. However, moves to force members of the ultra-Orthodox Jewish community to serve are dividing the nation.

title.children: The IDF conscription issue causing tensions in Israeli families

image.altText: An asian man with black hair looks grim in a blue suit and purple tie in front of a microphone

props.synopsis: Chinese military exercises near Taiwan on Monday were punishment for Taiwanese President Lai Ching-te's continued promotion of "separatism", according to a stern statement out of Beijing.

title.children: China says military exercises near Taiwan are punishment for 'separatism'

image.altText: exterior of a building that says law courts

props.synopsis: A man who sexually assaulted two of his daughters more than a dozen times has had his jail term cut after an appeals court found the sentence was "manifestly excessive".

title.children: 'Difficult day' as man who raped daughters has sentence cut by 18 years

image.altText: a middle age man smiles while looking up towards the sky

props.synopsis: Lincoln Trainor arrived at university on the first day holding a pen and a notepad. Looking around, he realised he was the only student without a laptop. He is one of a growing number of Australians pursuing a new career later in life.

title.children: Jobless, Lincoln asked himself one question to decide what to do next

image.altText: An ASX board with ASX in focus and stock prices out of focus.

props.synopsis: Our share market and the ASX 200 are set to lift after a Wall Street bounce.  Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX set to lift as Wall Street bounces, Gold above $US3,000 an ounce

image.altText: A woman looks at the camera.

props.synopsis: Letby has been found guilty of killing eight babies and attempting to kill seven more, but experts say they believe the evidence that convicted her was "meaningless".

title.children: Lucy Letby calls for inquiry into baby deaths to be paused

props.synopsis: Around the clock coverage of news events as they break at home and abroad.

title.children: ABC News Channel live

image.altText: Taylah, wearing a blue football jersey, holds a ball, looking pensive.

props.synopsis: Taylah Moore is "terrified" that political agendas in America could influence Australian politics and result in her not being able to play in her community league.

title.children: Trans Aussie rules player 'terrified' her right to play could be taken away

image.altText: A horse with a harness coach.

props.synopsis: A Tasmanian harness racing inquiry has heard allegations of race fixing, illegal betting and horses being given cocaine before race meets. The state's opposition says the allegations should be referred to Tasmania police.

title.children: Horses on cocaine, race fixing among allegations at inquiry

image.altText: Two black in suits shake hands in front of a Canadian flag

props.synopsis: Canada's new prime minister is making his first foreign visit as leader to Paris, amid escalating trade tensions with US President Donald Trump.

title.children: Canada's PM strengthens ties with 'reliable allies' as he heads to Europe

image.altText: Neha Kumar kneeling beside her mother who lies on a hospital bed

props.synopsis: Screening rates in Australia's culturally and linguistically diverse communities are consistently lower than for the general population. Why is this, and what's the solution?

title.children: Stigma remains a barrier for CALD women to get screened for cancer

image.altText: A close up of a man in a fluro yellow shirt fiddling with a metal antenna.

props.synopsis: The first photo from an international telescope being built in the WA outback takes scientists one step closer to understanding the dawn of the universe.

title.children: First space image using world-leading telescope 'beyond what we hoped'

image.altText: A man with his back to the camera holds a newborn baby over his shoulder.

props.synopsis: A new study into how fathers manage the transition into parenthood reveals that new dads experience a range of complex emotions, including dad guilt and feeling like a passenger parent.

title.children: Do you suffer from dad guilt? Maybe you feel like a passenger parent

image.altText: Michaelia Cash in front of a shadow of Peter Dutton.

props.synopsis: The opposition labels new allegations of violence and organised crime within the embattled CFMEU as the "biggest corruption scandal in our country's history".

title.children: Coalition to introduce new mafia-style laws to stamp out 'union corruption'

image.altText: Hands clasping at prison cell bars, good generic for prison, detention, jail, confinement

props.synopsis: Right to Information documents show Tasmania's Risdon Prison site was in lockdown more than 6,000 times last year.

title.children: Greens say lockdowns in Tasmanian prisons show 'system in crisis'

image.altText: Monica Lewinsky smiles on a red carpet in a black shiny dress, her long brown hair out

props.synopsis: From Monica Lewinsky's reinvention, to an aged care serial killer, and a 1970s audio drama, these are the things we can't stop listening to this month.

title.children: Monica Lewinsky steps back into the spotlight with vulnerable new podcast

image.altText: A smiling older woman wearing spectacles poses for a family photo.

props.synopsis: About a dozen residents are locked in a bitter dispute with the operator of a retirement village on the West Australian coast. Lawyers say the situation is a sign of a deeply under-regulated system.

title.children: Family in legal dispute with retirement village that signed 92yo woman up to 'lease-for-life'

image.altText: Drone footage shows the inundation around Ingham.

props.synopsis: A flood watch is issued for the North Tropical Coast after widespread flooding in the same region last month.

title.children: Rain for Western Qld and another flood watch for disaster-struck north

image.altText: Key Assets social worker Lana Valenta holds a VR head set which she shows to foster carer Louise

props.synopsis: Foster carers are using virtual reality to view confronting situations dealing with themes such as domestic violence and emotional abuse through the eyes of children — and it's helping the carers to better understand the children's behaviour.

title.children: 'You're crying and nothing happens': VR is changing how foster carers think

image.altText: Light-coloured grapes hang on vines in a vineyard on a sunny day.

props.synopsis: It took Mark Walpole eight years to get the two varieties into Australia and this year will be the first vintage.

title.children: European grape varieties make Australian debut

image.altText: A $5 note on a white table. It is pink, purple and orange.

props.synopsis: The RBA says the $5 note's new theme, selected from more than 2,100 public submissions, will honour the emotional, spiritual, and physical connection of First Nations people to country.

title.children: New $5 banknote to celebrate First Nations ties to country

image.altText: A close-up of Jim Chalmers's face.

props.synopsis: Federal Treasurer Jim Chalmers confirms the brief era of budget surpluses will end next week, when he will hand down a budget in deficit.

title.children: Jim Chalmers confirms deficit in next week's federal budget

image.altText: A man wearing a red cap smiling at the camera

props.synopsis: A former youth pastor from a mega church in Adelaide's northern suburbs has been arrested in the United States on charges of possessing child sexual abuse material.

title.children: Former Adelaide pastor arrested in US over alleged child abuse material
